revised_title: Secondary Electronic Emissions from Metal Foils and Animal Tissues: A Study of Penetrating Radiation
tldr: This article investigates the relative sensitivity of small ionization chambers lined with various metal foils and animal tissues when exposed to beams of X-rays and gamma rays of different mean wavelengths. The authors found that the ionization current observed in the chambers depends on the material of the walls, and they discuss the factors affecting the secondary electronic emission from the walls. The study has implications for measuring the energy absorbed in living tissues when exposed to penetrating radiation.
